Package org.proto4j.graph

Class JBracketView<T>

java.lang.Object
java.awt.Component
java.awt.Container
javax.swing.JComponent
org.proto4j.graph.JBracketView<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of the elements of this bracket view
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.Scrollable
public class JBracketView<T>
extends javax.swing.JComponent
implements javax.swing.Scrollable, javax.accessibility.Accessible
A JBracketView is used to display two-dimensional tables of cells, whereby each column can have a variable amount of rows. A separate model, BracketModel, maintains the contents of this bracket view.

To get a basic understanding of how to use this view to display brackets in different forms, just take a look at the org.proto4j.testing.graph package and its classes. There will be a brief introduction of hwo to structure the brackets and its model.

The computing of each cell's position is done by a BracketLocator. By default, the BracketConstraints object is used as the locator if none has been set. It contains a default algorithm to compute the position of each cell according to its row and column.

JBracketView stores a set of attributes in a BracketConstraints object. By now, the following attributes are supported:

  • ipadX: The initial X-axis space (EmptyBorder.left and right)
  • ipadY: The initial Y-axis space (EmptyBorder.top and bottom)
  • bracketHeight: The height for each cell
  • bracketWidth: The width for each cell
  • spaceX: The horizontal space between two cells
  • spaceY: The initial vertical space between two cells
  • lineThickness: The line width
  • paintMode: The line drawing strategy

JBracketView doesn't implement scrolling directly. To create a view that scrolls, make it the viewport view of a JScrollPane. For example: 

     JScrollPane scrollPane = new JScrollPane(myView);
     //or
     JScrollPane scrollPane = new JScrollPane();
     scrollPane.getViewPort().setView(myView);

In order to paint all brackets efficiently, there is a BracketCellRenderer that is used as a "rubber stamp" to paint the cells. The default bracket model uses a LinkedList to store the columns and per column a synchronized ArrayList to store the value of each cell.

Currently, there are three different line drawing methods supported by this JBracketView. For more information about the line painting, see the BracketUtil documentation.

Important: Eventing and editing will be supported in future versions.

See Also:
BracketModel, BracketUtil, BracketCellRenderer, BracketLocator, BracketLinePainter, Serialized Form

  • Constructor Details

    • JBracketView

      public JBracketView()
      Creates an empty view with no model, no cell renderer and no line painter. The BracketConstraints object is created regardless.

    • JBracketView

      public JBracketView​(BracketModel<T> dataModel)
      Creates a new JBracketView with the given data model.
      Parameters:
      dataModel - the mode to use

    • JBracketView

      public JBracketView​(int initialRowCount, boolean elimination) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
      Creates a new JBracketView with the given initial row count. This constructor then calculates how much columns are needed for a simple elimination model.

      For instance, the initial row count of 4 will produce the following view with the option of elimination enabled: 

       +---------+
 | Bracket |
 +---------+
               +---------+
               | Bracket |
               +---------+
 +---------+
 | Bracket |
 +---------+
                            +---------+
                            | Bracket |
                            +---------+
 +---------+
 | Bracket |
 +---------+
               +---------+
               | Bracket |
               +---------+
 +---------+
 | Bracket |
 +---------+
      The lines between these brackets would be painted be the current BracketLinePainter if one has been set.
      Parameters:
      initialRowCount - the row count of the first column
      elimination - tells the constructor whether the row count of each column should be decreased
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if elimination is enabled and the row count is not a multiple of 2.

    • JBracketView

      public JBracketView​(T[] elements, boolean elimination) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
      Creates a new JBracketView with the given initial (or full) data. Note that all columns and rows needed for this view are created via the JBracketView(int, boolean) constructor.

      All values stored in the given array will be inserted into the current data model.

      Parameters:
      elements - the initial elements
      elimination - tells the constructor whether the row count of each column should be decreased
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if elimination is enabled and the row count is not a multiple of 2 or the given array is null.

    • JBracketView

      public JBracketView​(T[] elements, int columns, int rows) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
      Creates a new JBracketView with its values aligned as a simple two-dimensional grid.

      Warning: in order to align all brackets/cells in a grid, this constructor sets a new BracketLocator by calling BracketLocator.asGrid().

      Parameters:
      elements - the elements to add
      columns - the amount of columns to create
      rows - the amount of rows per column
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any of the given arguments does not match its rules.
      See Also:
      BracketLocator.asGrid()

    • getNextPosition

      public java.awt.Point getNextPosition​(java.util.function.Predicate<? super T> predicate)
      Returns the next BracketModel position that matches the given Predicate. Note that the iteration starts at columnCount - 2 and moves backwards to 0.

      The returned point can be used to get the value of the next bracket/ cell: 

       
  BracketModel<Integer> model = view.getModel();
  Point next = view.getNextPosition(x -> x == 10);

  Integer nextValue = mode.getValueAt(next.x, next.y);
      Parameters:
      predicate - the filter to use
      Returns:
      the model position for the filtered cell

    • getPreferredScrollableViewportSize

      public java.awt.Dimension getPreferredScrollableViewportSize()
      Computes the size of viewport.
      Specified by:

      Returns:
      the preferredSize of a JViewport whose view is this Scrollable

    • getScrollableUnitIncrement

      public int getScrollableUnitIncrement​(java.awt.Rectangle visibleRect, int orientation, int direction)
      Returns the distance to scroll to expose the next or previous row (for vertical scrolling) or column (for horizontal scrolling).

      Specified by:
      getScrollableUnitIncrement in interface javax.swing.Scrollable
      Parameters:
      visibleRect - The view area visible within the viewport
      orientation - Either SwingConstants#VERTICAL or SwingConstants#HORIZONTAL.
      direction - Less than zero to scroll up/left, greater than zero for down/right.
      Returns:
      The "unit" increment for scrolling in the specified direction. This value should always be positive.
      See Also:
      JScrollBar.setUnitIncrement(int)

    • getScrollableBlockIncrement

      public int getScrollableBlockIncrement​(java.awt.Rectangle visibleRect, int orientation, int direction)
      For horizontal scrolling orientation, returns visibleRect.width.
      Specified by:
      getScrollableBlockIncrement in interface javax.swing.Scrollable
      Parameters:
      visibleRect - The view area visible within the viewport
      orientation - Either SwingConstants.VERTICAL or SwingConstants.HORIZONTAL.
      direction - Less than zero to scroll up/left, greater than zero for down/right.
      Returns:
      The "block" increment for scrolling in the specified direction. This value should always be positive.
      See Also:
      JScrollBar.setBlockIncrement(int)

    • getScrollableTracksViewportWidth

      public boolean getScrollableTracksViewportWidth()
      Don't track the viewport's width. This allows horizontal scrolling if the JViewport is itself embedded in a JScrollPane.
      Specified by:
      getScrollableTracksViewportWidth in interface javax.swing.Scrollable
      Returns:
      True if a viewport should force the Scrollable width to match its own.

    • getScrollableTracksViewportHeight

      public boolean getScrollableTracksViewportHeight()
      Don't track the viewport's height. This allows vertical scrolling if the JViewport is itself embedded in a JScrollPane.
      Specified by:
      getScrollableTracksViewportHeight in interface javax.swing.Scrollable
      Returns:
      True if a viewport should force the Scrollable height to match its own.
